comment.author: 42264328@N00
comment._content: A Google books entry from The Adventure Beautiful, a quote: Madame de Meissner is the daughter of the late Admiral Radford USN and the widow of a Russian diplomat She is a woman of purely social life the life of great embassies and courts but she has the psychic gift. She is mentioned in connection with the victims of the Titanic--managed to make contact with one of them, apparently--quite a feat. Seems like this is probably that woman, but who knows for sure?

comment.author: 10799299@N00
comment._content:
Her obituary from the Washington Post:

Apr 19, 1957
Mrs. De Meissner,102; Novelist and Translator 

Sophie Radford de Meissner, 102, widow of a Russian diplomat who was the first American woman to translate a Russian play into English, died yesterday at the Home for Incurables, 3720 Upton st. nw., after a long illness.

comment.author: 42264328@N00
comment._content: Doing a little more searching, it seems her father was William Radford (1808 -1890), see Wikipedia. She wrote a biography of her father, Old Naval Days: Sketches from the Life of Rear Admiral William Radford, U. S. N. By Sophie Radford de Meissner, H. Holt and company, 1920, see Google Books. It sounds like she was quite the character.
